\section{Generation of MATH: Counting and Probability}
\label{sec:generation-MATH-Counting-and-Probability}

\begin{longtable}{|l|p{8cm}|p{8cm}|} 
\caption{New questions generated from Counting \& Probability questions in the MATH dataset, and the closest question among the existing questions.}\\
\hline
\textbf{ID} & \textbf{Auto-Generated question} & \textbf{Closest question in the dataset}\\
\hline
1 & How many ways are there to divide a set of $10$ objects into two sets of equal size?& 
Compute $\dbinom{8}{4}$.
\\
\hline
2 & How many ways are there to tile a $4\times 4$ square with $1\times 1$ squares?& 
In how many ways can George choose two out of seven colors to paint his room?
\\
\hline
3 & How many ways are there to place a black and a white knight on a $3\times 3$ chessboard so that they do not attack each other?&
How many odd numbers between $100$ and $999$ have distinct digits?
\\
\hline
4 & A regular $n$-sided polygon is inscribed in a circle of radius $r$. The area of the polygon is $m$, and the area of the circle is $n$. Find $m + n.$
& 
In how many ways can George choose two out of seven colors to paint his room?
\\ 
\hline
5 & How many ways are there to place a $2\times 2$ grid of squares on a $4\times 4$ chessboard so that no two squares are adjacent?& 
In how many ways can George choose two out of seven colors to paint his room?
\\
\hline
6 & A standard six-sided fair die is rolled four times. The probability that the product of all four numbers rolled is a perfect square is $\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $m-n$.&
A standard six-sided fair die is rolled four times. The probability that the product of all four numbers rolled is a perfect square is $\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $m+n$.
\\
\hline
7 & How many ways are there to place $n$ distinguishable objects into $n$ indistinguishable boxes?& 
In how many ways can George choose two out of seven colors to paint his room?
\\
\hline
8 & How many ways are there to fill a $4\times 4$ grid with $1$s and $0$s, if each row and each column must have exactly $2$ $1$s? & 
In how many ways can George choose two out of seven colors to paint his room?
\\
\hline
9 & How many ways are there to tile a $4\times 4$ square with $1\times 2$ rectangles? & 
In how many ways can George choose two out of seven colors to paint his room?
\\
\hline
10 & How many ways are there to place a non-attacking white and black pawn on a $4\times 4$ chessboard? & 
How many odd numbers between $100$ and $999$ have distinct digits?
\\
\hline
\end{longtable}
title: A Neural Network Solves, Explains, and Generates University Math Problems by Program Synthesis and Few-Shot Learning at Human Level
